title: The effects of underwater pressure on the body - Neosha S Kashef

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the bodily damage caused by rapid changes in pressure experienced by a fish when reeled up to the surface?

options.label: A
options.text: Decompression

options.label: B
options.text: barotrauma

options.label: C
options.text: decompression sickness

options.label: D
options.text: exophthalmia

multiple-choice.question: According to Boyle's gas law, what happens to the volume of a gas when pressure increases?

options.label: A
options.text: it expands

options.label: B
options.text: it remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: it compresses

options.label: D
options.text: it diffuses

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition where the eyes of a fish bulge out of their sockets due to increased internal pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: exophthalmia

options.label: B
options.text: decompression sickness

options.label: C
options.text: barotrauma

options.label: D
options.text: recompression

multiple-choice.question: What is the law that states the amount of a gas that dissolves in a liquid is proportional to its partial pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: Boyle's gas law

options.label: B
options.text: Henry's law

options.label: C
options.text: Pascal's principle

options.label: D
options.text: Archimedes' principle

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the nitrogen in a scuba tank when a diver ascends too quickly?

options.label: A
options.text: it diffuses out of the tank

options.label: B
options.text: it dissolves in the water

options.label: C
options.text: it forms microbubbles in the diver's tissues

options.label: D
options.text: it escapes through the regulator

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the condition where a diver experiences severe pain and sometimes even death due to the formation of microbubbles in their tissues?

options.label: A
options.text: decompression sickness

options.label: B
options.text: barotrauma

options.label: C
options.text: exophthalmia

options.label: D
options.text: recompression sickness

multiple-choice.question: How can a diver avoid falling victim to decompression sickness?

options.label: A
options.text: by ascending quickly

options.label: B
options.text: by taking regular breaks during ascent

options.label: C
options.text: by holding their breath

options.label: D
options.text: by equalizing their ears only

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process of reducing gas volume in a fish's body by returning it to the correct depth?

options.label: A
options.text: recompression

options.label: B
options.text: decompression

options.label: C
options.text: exophthalmia

options.label: D
options.text: D recompression

multiple-choice.question: Why should a fisherman not pierce the stomach of an inflated fish with a needle to let air escape?

options.label: A
options.text: because it will cause more damage

options.label: B
options.text: because it will not work

options.label: C
options.text: because it will make the fish more buoyant

options.label: D
options.text: because it will attract predators

multiple-choice.question: What is the proper way to return a fish to its habitat after it has been reeled up to the surface?

options.label: A
options.text: by releasing it at the surface

options.label: B
options.text: by releasing it at the correct depth using a descending device

options.label: C
options.text: by throwing it back into the water

options.label: D
options.text: by letting it swim back down on its own

title: What did democracy really mean in Athens? - Melissa Schwartzberg

multiple-choice.question: In ancient Athens, what was the primary method of filling most offices in the government?

options.label: A
options.text: Election by the people

options.label: B
options.text: Appointment by a governing council

options.label: C
options.text: Random lottery from a pool of citizen volunteers

options.label: D
options.text: Hereditary succession

options.label: A
options.text: The Boule

options.label: B
options.text: The Ecclesia

options.label: C
options.text: The Senate

options.label: D
options.text: The Council of Elders

multiple-choice.question: What was the principle that guided the Athenian system of government, allowing any citizen to participate in the decision-making process?

options.label: A
options.text: Ho boulomenos (Anyone who wishes)

options.label: B
options.text: Democracy by the few

options.label: C
options.text: Rule by the aristocracy

options.label: D
options.text: Anarchy

multiple-choice.question: In ancient Athens, what positions were filled by election, as opposed to sortition?

options.label: A
options.text: Generals and military commanders

options.label: B
options.text: Members of the Boule

options.label: C
options.text: Jurors and magistrates

options.label: D
options.text: Citizens' representatives

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the process of randomized selection used in ancient Athens to fill certain positions in the government?

options.label: A
options.text: Sortition

options.label: B
options.text: Election

options.label: C
options.text: Appointment

options.label: D
options.text: Hereditary succession

options.label: A
options.text: Women, slaves, and foreigners

options.label: B
options.text: Men, slaves, and foreigners

options.label: C
options.text: Women, men, and slaves

options.label: D
options.text: Only foreigners

multiple-choice.question: What was the concern of some ancient philosophers, including Plato, about the Athenian system of government?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That it was too aristocratic

options.label: C
options.text: That it was anarchic and run by fools

multiple-choice.question: What is a modern example of how the democratic principle behind sortition still survives today?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Citizens' assemblies and deliberative polls

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the main reason for the Athenian system of government to rely on a 500-member governing council (the Boule)?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a check on the power of the people

options.label: B
options.text: To set the agenda and evaluate proposals

options.label: C
options.text: To elect the leaders of the government

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: That it poses problems, including the influence of wealth and the emergence of professional politicians with different interests than their constituents

options.label: C
options.text: That it is a more effective way of governing

options.label: D
options.text: That it is a less democratic way of governing

title: Where did Earth’s water come from? - Zachary Metz

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the Earth's surface is covered by water?
What is the approximate percentage of our bodies that is made up of water?
What is the process known as that occurs at the center of stars and results in the formation of heavier elements like beryllium, carbon, and oxygen?

options.label: A
options.text: Nucleosynthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Nuclear Fission

options.label: C
options.text: Chemical Reaction

options.label: D
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: A
options.text: Outgassing

options.label: B
options.text: Volcanic Eruption

options.label: C
options.text: Weathering

options.label: D
options.text: Erosion

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Evaporation Theory

options.label: C
options.text: Condensation Theory

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the process by which ice-bearing comets or asteroids bombarded the Earth over millions of years, bringing water to the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: Impact Theory

options.label: B
options.text: Accretion Theory

options.label: C
options.text: Outgassing Theory

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Iron Meteorite

options.label: C
options.text: Stony Meteorite

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

options.label: A
options.text: Life may have formed much later than previously thought

options.label: B
options.text: The Earth's atmosphere may have formed much earlier than previously thought

options.label: C
options.text: The water on Earth may have come from a nearby lake or river

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the chaotic and cosmic journey that the water on Earth underwent before reaching the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: The water was formed in the Earth's core

options.label: B
options.text: The water was brought by ice-bearing comets or asteroids

options.label: C
options.text: The water was present in the dusty cloud that formed the solar system

options.label: D

title: Can robots be creative? - Gil Weinberg

multiple-choice.question: Who is considered the world's first computer programmer?

options.label: A
options.text: Charles Babbage

options.label: B
options.text: Ada Lovelace

options.label: C
options.text: Alan Turing

options.label: D
options.text: John von Neumann

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the test proposed to scrutinize the idea of artificial intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Turing Test

options.label: B
options.text: Lovelace Test

options.label: C
options.text: Evolutionary Test

options.label: D
options.text: Creativity Test

multiple-choice.question: According to the Lovelace Test, a machine can pass it if it can produce an outcome that its designers cannot explain based on their original code. What is the implication of this test?

options.label: A
options.text: It implies that machines can never be creative

options.label: B
options.text: It implies that machines can be creative, but only if they can explain their process

options.label: C
options.text: It implies that machines can be creative if they can produce an outcome that their designers cannot explain

options.label: D
options.text: It implies that machines are not intelligent

multiple-choice.question: What is an evolutionary algorithm, also known as a genetic algorithm?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of artificial intelligence that uses machine learning

options.label: B
options.text: A type of algorithm that mimics biological evolution

options.label: C
options.text: A type of programming language that uses random number generators

options.label: D
options.text: A type of database that stores large amounts of data

multiple-choice.question: How does the fitness function in an evolutionary algorithm work?

options.label: A
options.text: It selects the most similar phrases to the original input

options.label: B
options.text: It selects the least similar phrases to the original input

options.label: C
options.text: It selects the phrases that are most similar to an external melody chosen by human musicians

options.label: D
options.text: It selects the phrases that are least similar to an external melody chosen by human musicians

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of applying mutation and recombination in an evolutionary algorithm?

options.label: A
options.text: To select the most similar phrases to the original input

options.label: B
options.text: To select the least similar phrases to the original input

options.label: C
options.text: To create new generations of phrases by switching, combining, and replacing random notes

options.label: D
options.text: To apply an external fitness function to the phrases

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Lovelace Test in determining machine creativity?

options.label: A
options.text: It implies that machines can never be creative

options.label: B
options.text: It implies that machines can be creative, but only if they can explain their process

options.label: C
options.text: It implies that machines can be creative if they can produce an outcome that their designers cannot explain

options.label: D
options.text: It implies that machines are not intelligent

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between human aesthetic and machine creativity?

options.label: A
options.text: Human aesthetic is necessary for machine creativity

options.label: B
options.text: Human aesthetic is not necessary for machine creativity

options.label: C
options.text: Human aesthetic is a factor in machine creativity, but not the only one

options.label: D
options.text: Human aesthetic is not related to machine creativity

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of programmers in machine creativity?

options.label: A
options.text: Programmers are not involved in machine creativity

options.label: B
options.text: Programmers are involved in machine creativity, but only as designers

options.label: C
options.text: Programmers are involved in machine creativity, but their role is limited to writing code

options.label: D
options.text: Programmers are involved in machine creativity, and their role is not limited to writing code

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of machine creativity initiatives?

options.label: A
options.text: To create machines that can only produce original and valuable outcomes

options.label: B
options.text: To create machines that can only produce outcomes that are pleasing to humans

options.label: C
options.text: To create machines that can produce outcomes that are pleasing to humans, and also meet certain criteria

options.label: D
options.text: To create machines that can produce outcomes that are pleasing to humans, and also meet certain criteria, and are also creative

title: Plato’s Allegory of the Cave - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: Who is the Greek philosopher that envisioned the ideal society by examining concepts like justice, truth, and beauty in his Allegory of the Cave?

options.label: A
options.text: Socrates

options.label: B
options.text: Plato

options.label: C
options.text: Aristotle

options.label: D
options.text: Epicurus

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary idea presented in Plato's Allegory of the Cave?

options.label: A
options.text: The nature of reality is a reflection of our perceptions.

options.label: B
options.text: The ideal society is one where philosopher kings rule.

options.label: C
options.text: The Allegory of the Cave describes the process of enlightenment.

options.label: D
options.text: The cave represents a physical location where prisoners are chained.

multiple-choice.question: According to the Allegory of the Cave, what is the primary source of light for the prisoners?

options.label: A
options.text: The fire behind them

options.label: B
options.text: The sunlight from outside

options.label: C
options.text: The objects carried by people passing by

options.label: D
options.text: The shadows on the wall

options.label: A
options.text: They welcome him back with open arms

options.label: B
options.text: They are indifferent to his return

options.label: C
options.text: They think he has become stupid and blind

options.label: D
options.text: They are angry that he left

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the primary purpose of the Allegory of the Cave?

options.label: A
options.text: To describe the ideal society

options.label: B
options.text: To illustrate the theory of forms

options.label: C
options.text: To portray the process of enlightenment

options.label: D
options.text: To disparage Athenian democracy

multiple-choice.question: What is the theory of forms, as developed in Plato's other dialogues?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that things in the physical world are flawed reflections of ideal forms

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that the physical world is the only reality

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that the mind is the only reality

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the theory of forms connected to the Allegory of the Cave?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, it is the central idea of the Allegory

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it is a related idea

options.label: C
options.text: No, it is not mentioned in the Allegory

options.label: D
options.text: No, it is a separate idea

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary question that the Allegory of the Cave raises, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The origin of knowledge

options.label: B
options.text: The problem of representation

options.label: C
options.text: The nature of reality itself

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the primary reaction of the masses to the idea of philosopher kings?

options.label: A
options.text: They welcome the idea with open arms

options.label: B
options.text: They are indifferent to the idea

options.label: C
options.text: They think it is a bad idea

options.label: D
options.text: They are hostile to the idea

options.label: A
options.text: Truth or fiction

options.label: B
options.text: Light or darkness

options.label: C
options.text: Truth or habit

options.label: D
options.text: Light or shadow

title: Why it’s so hard to cure HIV/AIDS - Janet Iwasa

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the case of a man who was cured of HIV in 2008?

options.label: A
options.text: He was the first person to contract HIV.

options.label: B
options.text: He was the first person to die from AIDS.

options.label: C
options.text: He was the first person to be cured of HIV.

options.label: D
options.text: He was the first person to be infected with HIV through a blood transfusion.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two major catches of antiretroviral therapy for HIV-positive patients?

options.label: A
options.text: They must take the drugs for a certain period, and then they can stop.

options.label: B
options.text: They must take the drugs for the rest of their lives, and without them, the virus can make a comeback.

options.label: C
options.text: They must take the drugs only when they are experiencing symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: They must take the drugs only when they are in a high-risk situation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way HIV infects people?

options.label: A
options.text: Through air, water, or casual contact.

options.label: B
options.text: Through exchanges of bodily fluids.

options.label: C
options.text: Through a bite from an infected mosquito.

options.label: D
options.text: Through a contaminated food or water source.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of helper T cells in the immune system?

options.label: A
options.text: They help defend the body against bacterial and fungal infections.

options.label: B
options.text: They help defend the body against viral infections.

options.label: C
options.text: They help defend the body against parasitic infections.

options.label: D
options.text: They help defend the body against autoimmune diseases.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the stage of HIV infection when T cell counts drop too low?

options.label: A
options.text: AIDS

options.label: B
options.text: HIV

options.label: C
options.text: HIV infection

options.label: D
options.text: HIV replication

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way HIV drugs work?

options.label: A
options.text: They prevent the viral genome from being copied and incorporated into a host cell's DNA.

options.label: B
options.text: They prevent the virus from maturing or assembling, causing HIV to be unable to infect new cells in the body.

options.label: C
options.text: They activate all cells harboring the HIV genetic information.

options.label: D
options.text: They cut the HIV DNA out of cells' genomes altogether.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to cure HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the virus is too complex to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the virus hides out somewhere our current drugs cannot reach it: inside the DNA of healthy T cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the virus is too contagious.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the virus is too rare.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in developing a cure for HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: It is too expensive to develop a cure.

options.label: B
options.text: It is too difficult to understand the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: A mix of political, economic, and cultural barriers makes effective prevention and treatment difficult.

options.label: D
options.text: It is too time-consuming to develop a cure.

multiple-choice.question: What is one research approach to developing a true cure for HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a drug to activate all cells harboring the HIV genetic information.

options.label: B
options.text: Using genetic tools to cut the HIV DNA out of cells' genomes altogether.

options.label: C
options.text: Using a combination of both approaches.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no research approach to developing a true cure for HIV.

multiple-choice.question: Why is there hope for developing a cure for HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the virus is too rare.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the virus is too complex to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we now know that a cure is possible, and that may give us what we need to beat HIV for good.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the virus is too contagious.

title: How does the thyroid manage your metabolism? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of the thyroid gland in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce antibodies to fight off infections

options.label: B
options.text: To make sure that the cells in the body are working properly

options.label: C
options.text: To produce red blood cells

options.label: D
options.text: To filter waste from the blood

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin and glucagon

options.label: C
options.text: Adrenaline and noradrenaline

options.label: D
options.text: Growth hormone and prolactin

options.text: Hyperthyroidism, characterized by a slower metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: Hypothyroidism, characterized by a slower metabolism

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperthyroidism, characterized by a faster metabolism

options.label: D
options.text: No effect on the body's metabolism

options.text: To produce hormones that stimulate the thyroid gland

options.label: B
options.text: To produce hormones that inhibit the thyroid gland

options.label: C
options.text: To sense if hormone levels in the blood are too low or too high

options.label: D
options.text: To filter waste from the blood

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperthyroidism, characterized by a faster metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: Hypothyroidism, characterized by a slower metabolism

options.label: C
options.text: No effect on the body's metabolism

options.label: D
options.text: Weight gain and sluggishness

options.text: To instruct every cell in the body when to consume oxygen and nutrients

options.label: B
options.text: To produce red blood cells

options.label: C
options.text: To filter waste from the blood

options.label: D
options.text: To produce antibodies to fight off infections

options.label: A
options.text: To slow down the body's metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: To speed up the body's metabolism

options.label: C
options.text: To have no effect on the body's metabolism

options.label: D
options.text: To produce red blood cells

options.label: A
options.text: The cells become overactive and consume too many nutrients and oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: The cells become listless and consume too few nutrients and oxygen

options.label: C
options.text: The cells have no effect on the body's metabolism

options.label: D
options.text: The cells produce red blood cells

options.label: A
options.text: To decrease the body's energy levels

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the body's energy levels

options.label: C
options.text: To have no effect on the body's energy levels

options.label: D

options.text: To produce hormones that stimulate the thyroid gland

options.text: Scientific theories

options.text: Philosophical concepts

options.label: D

options.text: To analyze the variance in Shakespeare's works

options.label: D

title: What does the pancreas do? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The pancreas is located above the stomach.

options.label: B
options.text: The pancreas is located behind the stomach.

options.label: C
options.text: The pancreas is located in the heart.

options.label: D
options.text: The pancreas is located in the lungs.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The pancreas is responsible for breaking down proteins.

options.label: B
options.text: The pancreas is responsible for breaking down carbohydrates.

options.label: C
options.text: The pancreas is responsible for breaking down fats and producing digestive enzymes.

options.label: D
options.text: The pancreas is responsible for breaking down sugars.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question

options.label: A
options.text: If blood sugar is high, the pancreas will release insulin to store excess sugar in the liver.

options.label: B
options.text: If blood sugar is low, the pancreas will release glucagon to release stored sugars from the liver.

options.label: C
options.text: If blood sugar is high, the pancreas will release glucagon to release stored sugars from the liver.

options.label: D
options.text: If blood sugar is low, the pancreas will release insulin to store excess sugar in the liver.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question

options.label: A
options.text: The pancreas works alone to keep us healthy.

options.label: B
options.text: The pancreas needs our conscious participation to work effectively.

options.label: C
options.text: The pancreas is responsible for breaking down all nutrients.

options.label: D
options.text: The pancreas is not responsible for controlling blood sugar levels.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The pancreas produces insulin and glucagon to control blood sugar levels.

options.label: B
options.text: The pancreas produces only insulin to control blood sugar levels.

options.label: C
options.text: The pancreas produces only glucagon to control blood sugar levels.

options.label: D
options.text: The pancreas does not produce insulin or glucagon.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin makes excess sugar move into cells for storage.

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin makes excess sugar move into cells for energy use.

options.label: C
options.text: Insulin tells the liver to shut down sugar production.

options.label: D
options.text: Insulin tells the body's cells to release stored sugars.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question

options.label: A
options.text: If the pancreas is weakened by disease, it will produce more insulin.

options.label: B
options.text: If the pancreas is weakened by disease, it will produce less insulin.

options.label: C
options.text: If the pancreas is weakened by disease, it will produce the same amount of insulin.

options.label: D
options.text: If the pancreas is weakened by disease, it will produce more glucagon.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question

options.label: A
options.text: A faulty pancreas can no longer control blood sugar levels.

options.label: B
options.text: A faulty pancreas can still produce insulin and glucagon.

options.label: C
options.text: A faulty pancreas is not responsible for controlling blood sugar levels.

options.label: D
options.text: A faulty pancreas will produce more glucagon.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question

options.label: A
options.text: Diabetes is caused by a lack of insulin production.

options.label: B
options.text: Diabetes is caused by an excess of insulin production.

options.label: C
options.text: Diabetes is caused by a lack of glucagon production.

options.label: D
options.text: Diabetes is caused by an excess of glucagon production.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question

options.label: A
options.text: The pancreas is responsible for breaking down proteins, fats, and carbohydrates.

options.label: B
options.text: The pancreas is responsible for producing insulin and glucagon.

options.label: C
options.text: The pancreas is responsible for controlling blood sugar levels.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

title: Why do buildings fall in earthquakes? - Vicki V. May

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason buildings collapse during an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: The earthquake itself causes the building to collapse.

options.label: B
options.text: The ground beneath the building shakes violently, or splits apart.

options.label: C
options.text: The building's mass and stiffness cause it to vibrate back and forth.

options.label: D
options.text: The building's foundation displaces the lower levels, sending shock waves through the structure.

multiple-choice.question: Which factor determines a building's natural frequency?

options.label: A
options.text: Its mass and stiffness

options.label: B
options.text: Its height and material type

options.label: C
options.text: Its location and soil type

options.label: D
options.text: Its shape and columns

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect known as resonance in the context of earthquakes and building collapse?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in the building's natural frequency.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in the building's stiffness.

options.label: C
options.text: A situation where the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves matches the building's natural frequency.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of shock absorption system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of engineers working with geologists and seismologists to predict earthquake motions at building sites?

options.label: A
options.text: To design buildings that are as tall as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent resonance-induced collapses.

options.label: C
options.text: To create the sturdiest buildings possible.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new materials for building construction.

multiple-choice.question: Which type of building is more susceptible to damage from low frequencies of motion?

options.label: A
options.text: Taller and more flexible buildings.

options.label: B
options.text: Shorter and stiffer buildings.

options.label: C
options.text: Buildings with a high natural frequency.

options.label: D
options.text: Buildings with a low natural frequency.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a tuned mass damper system?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase a building's natural frequency.

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease a building's stiffness.

options.label: C
options.text: To cancel out resonance by oscillating out of phase with the building's natural frequency.

options.label: D
options.text: To absorb shocks and limit deformation.

multiple-choice.question: Which type of building is less damaged during an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: Buildings between six and fifteen stories tall.

options.label: B
options.text: Buildings taller than fifteen stories.

options.label: C
options.text: Shorter buildings.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a building's mass and its natural frequency?

options.label: A
options.text: They are directly proportional.

options.label: B
options.text: They are inversely proportional.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no relationship.

options.label: D
options.text: They are proportional to each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of base isolation in earthquake-resistant design?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase a building's natural frequency.

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease a building's stiffness.

options.label: C
options.text: To isolate the foundation's displacement from the rest of the building.

options.label: D
options.text: To cancel out resonance.

multiple-choice.question: According to the text, what is the key to building earthquake-resistance?

options.label: A
options.text: Building the sturdiest buildings possible.

options.label: B
options.text: Building shorter buildings.

options.label: C
options.text: Building the smartest buildings possible.

options.label: D
options.text: Building on bedrock.

title: Why the Arctic is climate change's canary in the coal mine - William Chapman

multiple-choice.question: What is the Arctic often described as in terms of predicting the impact of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: The bellwether

options.label: B
options.text: The canary in the coal mine

options.label: C
options.text: The laboratory

options.label: D
options.text: The observatory

multiple-choice.question: What type of surfaces are very effective at reflecting the sun's energy back into space?

options.label: A
options.text: Dark land and water surfaces

options.label: B
options.text: White surfaces like snow and ice

options.label: C
options.text: C: Forests and grasslands

options.label: D
options.text: Urban areas

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the ground and ocean underneath when the Arctic warms and some of the snow and ice melts?

options.label: A
options.text: They cool down

options.label: B
options.text: They remain the same

options.label: C
options.text: They absorb more incoming sunlight

options.label: D
options.text: They reflect more sunlight

multiple-choice.question: What is another feedback mechanism through insulation that Arctic sea ice is responsible for?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of positive feedback loop

options.label: B
options.text: A type of negative feedback loop

options.label: C
options.text: A type of insulation that prevents heat from escaping

options.label: D
options.text: A type of insulation that prevents heat from entering

options.label: A
options.text: It cools down

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: It warms up

options.label: D
options.text: It stays neutral

options.label: A
options.text: A positive feedback loop

options.label: B
options.text: A negative feedback loop

options.label: C
options.text: A type of insulation

options.label: D
options.text: A type of reflection

options.label: A
options.text: It cools down

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: It warms up

options.label: D
options.text: It stays neutral

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the feedback loop when the increased moisture and clouds trap the Earth's heat during the Arctic winters?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes negative

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes positive

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes neutral

options.label: A
options.text: Faster jet stream winds

options.label: B
options.text: Slower jet stream winds

options.label: C
options.text: More linear atmospheric circulation

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Short-term fluctuations

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: McDonald's Cup Sizes Around The World

title: The great conspiracy against Julius Caesar - Kathryn Tempest

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the senators who feared Julius Caesar's rise to power?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed he was not a good leader.

options.label: B
options.text: They feared a return to the monarchy.

options.label: C
options.text: They wanted to gain more power for themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: They thought he was too old to rule.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Julius Caesar being made dictator perpetuo in 44 BCE?

options.label: A
options.text: It gave him the power to make laws without consulting the senate.

options.label: B
options.text: It granted him temporary emergency powers in wartime.

options.label: C
options.text: It made him the wealthiest man in Rome.

options.label: D
options.text: It gave him the power to appoint his own successor.

multiple-choice.question: What was the role of Mark Antony in the aftermath of Julius Caesar's assassination?

options.label: A
options.text: He led the conspiracy against Caesar.

options.label: B
options.text: He delivered a passionate speech at Caesar's funeral that whipped the crowd into a frenzy.

options.label: C
options.text: He was one of the senators who fled Rome after Caesar's assassination.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a close advisor to Brutus.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the power vacuum that followed Julius Caesar's assassination?

options.label: A
options.text: The Roman Republic was strengthened.

options.label: B
options.text: The concentration of power under the office of Emperor was ended.

options.label: C
options.text: A series of civil wars broke out.

options.label: D
options.text: The senate regained its power.

multiple-choice.question: What was the legacy of Brutus according to Dante's "Inferno"?

options.label: A
options.text: He was placed in the center of Hell and eternally chewed by Satan himself.

options.label: B
options.text: He was placed in the center of Heaven and eternally praised by God.

options.label: C
options.text: He was placed in the center of Purgatory and eternally purified.

options.label: D
options.text: He was not mentioned at all.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the title "liberators" given to the conspirators who assassinated Julius Caesar?

options.label: A
options.text: It signified their desire to free Rome from tyranny.

options.label: B
options.text: It signified their desire to gain more power for themselves.

options.label: C
options.text: It signified their desire to restore the monarchy.

options.label: D
options.text: It signified their desire to weaken the Roman Republic.

multiple-choice.question: What was the role of Gaius Cassius Longinus in the conspiracy against Julius Caesar?

options.label: A
options.text: He was the leader of the conspiracy.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a close advisor to Brutus.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a senator who fled Rome after Caesar's assassination.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a close friend and brother-in-law of Brutus.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Brutus's decision to join the conspiracy against Julius Caesar?

options.label: A
options.text: He was hailed as a hero by the Roman public.

options.label: B
options.text: He was forced out of Rome.

options.label: C
options.text: He took his own life.

options.label: D
options.text: He was placed in the center of Hell by Dante.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the phrase "Et tu, Brute?" in the context of Julius Caesar's assassination?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a phrase written by Shakespeare that was not actually spoken by Caesar.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a phrase spoken by Caesar to Brutus as he was being attacked.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a phrase spoken by Brutus to Caesar as he was being attacked.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a phrase spoken by Mark Antony at Caesar's funeral.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relevance of the story of Julius Caesar's assassination today?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a historical event that is no longer relevant to modern society.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a cautionary tale about the dangers of ambition and the importance of personal loyalties.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a story about the rise and fall of a great leader.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a story about the importance of following orders without question.
